column2: Access:              http://libweb5.princeton.edu/visual_materials/gates/images/princetonmeso4.jpgAvailability:        Check the catalogs in your library. Libraries worldwide that own item: 1 Search the HOLLIS CatalogExternal Resources:  Cite This ItemFind Items About:    Book of the Chilam Balam of Chumayel1Chilam Balam de Chumayel (Manuscript)62Carrillo y Ancona, Crescencio,max: 29Title:                Book of the Chilam Balam of Chumayel,[between 1775 and 1800].Author(s):           Carrillo y Ancona, Crescencio,; 1837-1897, ; former owner.Place:               Mexico; Yucatán; Chumayel.Year:                1775-1800?Description:         1 volumes (58 leaves) : paper, illustrations ; 20 x 16 cmLanguage:            Mayan languages; Text in Yucatec with some Spanish.Abstract:            Manuscript, written and illustrated in Chumayel, Yucatán, probably dates to the late 18th century, cf. Edmondson, Berrera, and Roys. Concerns the history of the conquest of theYucatán by the Spaniards. Includes the ritual of the four world-quarters; the rise of Hunac Ceel to power; a prophecy for Katun 11-Ahau; the building of the mounds; memoranda concerning the historyof Yucatán; notes on the calendar; the amorial bearings of Yucatán; notes on astronomy; the interrogation of the chiefs; the creation of the world; the rituals of the angels; a song of the Itza;the creation of the uinal; a history of the Spanish conquest; the prophecy of Chilam Balam and the story of Antonio Martinez; a chapter of questions and answers; an incantation; a series ofKatun-prophecies; chronicles; a book of Katun-prophecies; the last judgement; prophecies of a new religion, cf. Roys. There are inscriptions in Spanish and a native language throughout (1832-1838),including names, places, and dates. For example "Chumayel Junio 28. de 1838 Chilam Balam [por Pedro Bristano].References:          Cline, H.F. Guide to Ethnohistorical Sources,; 1146; Weeks, J.M. Mesoamerican Ethnohistory in United States Libraries,; 148Access:              Note:                Imagehttp://libweb5.princeton.edu/visual_materials/gates/images/princetonmeso4.jpgNote:                Finding aid or folder listhttp://libweb.princeton.edu/libraries/firestone/rbsc/aids/princetonmesoSUBJECT(S)Descriptor:          Mayas -- Antiquities.Mayas -- History.Mayas -- Religion.Maya language -- Texts.Mayas -- Antiquités.Mayas -- Histoire.Mayas -- Religion.Maya (Langue) -- Textes.Maya language.Mayas.Mayas -- Antiquities.Mayas -- Religion.Genre/Form:          Manuscripts, Maya -- 19th century.papers (documents)History.Texts.Wash drawings.Note(s):             Layout: 1 column, 32 lines./ Decoration: 27 leaves of illustration ranging from full-page drawings (in brown ink and red ink wash) to smaller ones on a portion of a textualpage./ Facsimile reproduction: The Book of the Chilam Balam of Chumayel / with introduction by G.B. Gordon. Philadelphia : University of Pennsylvania Museum, Anthropological Publications, v. 5,1913./ Published translation: The Chilam Balam of Chumayel / translated by Ralph L. Roys. Washington D.C. : Carnegie Institute of Washington, publication no. 438, 1933./ Published translation andtranscription: Heaven Born Merida and its Destiny, The Book of Chilam Balam of Chumayel / translated by Monro S. Edmundson. Austin : University of Texas Press, 1986.General Info:        Found in the 19th-century in Chumayel, probably by don Adumaro Molina; given to Bishop Crescencio Carrillo y Ancona; the manuscript was expropriated by the government of GeneralAlvarado (from Rivero Figueroa's library) in 1915; became part of the Cepeda Library in Merida and then disappeared; said to have belonged to Julio Berzunza in 1945./ Forms part of the PrincetonMesoamerican Collection (C0940). Preferred citation:  Princeton Mesoamerican Manuscripts, no. 4, Manuscripts Division, Dept. of Rare Books and Special Collections, Princeton University Library.; Bookof the Chilam Balam of Chumayel / Carl Hermann Berendt. Berendt Linquistics Collections 50. Philadelphia : University of Pennsylvania Museum, 1868.Other Titles:        Chilam Balam de Chumayel (Manuscript); Incipit:; U chin vucub icil an Canule: Ix jacMaterial Type:       Manuscript (mss)Document Type:       Book; Archival MaterialDate of Entry:       20011112Update:              20220507Accession No:        OCLC:                53266654Provider:        OCLCDatabase:            WorldCat--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Ayuntamiento deCampeche para pedir se lleve á efecto el plan de reforma propuesto por el Gobierno á la H. column2: Access:              http://libweb5.princeton.edu/visual_materials/gates/images/gates2.jpgAvailability:         Search the HOLLIS CatalogExternal Resources:  Cite This ItemFind Items About:    Chilam Balam de Nah (Manuscript)2Garrett, Robert,max: 37Gates, William,max: 156Title:                Book of the Chilam Balam of Nah :[1857-1863]. manuscript,Author(s):           Garrett, Robert,; 1875-1961, ; donor.Gates, William,; 1863-1940, ; former owner.Place:               Mexico; Yucatán (State); Teabo.Year:                1857-1863Description:         1 volumes (64 leaves) : paper, illustrations ; 22.5 x 17 cmIn:                  Robert Garrett Collection. 1500-1968Language:            Mayan languages; Text in Yucatec with some Spanish.Abstract:            Manuscript transcribed by Jose Maria Na and Jose Secundino Na of Teabo, Yucatán. The first p. 30 is signed by Jose Secundino Na and dated December 18, 1857. The final pages aresigned by Jose Maria Nah and dated August 5, 1863. The manuscript is divided into 2 parts: pages 1-30 constitute a liturgical calendar for an unspecified year, includes calendar count, with ancientdaynames, a section on astronomy; p. 30-53 are concerned with diseases and their cures. Page 1 is the seating of January; p. 2 is a correlation of the Gregorian calendar with the Maya months of anunspecified year; p. 3-14 correlates each day of the Gregorian year with the days of the Mayan tzolkin (there are no numbers with the Mayan days); the saint is given for each day, and up to p. 6, itis indicated whether the day has a good omen or bad. Pages 15-30 concern the signs of the zodiac, indicating the significance of the births under particular signs, and the advantages of burning,fields, etc. This portion of the book was composed in 1857. Pages 30-53 are "Libro u tial acob" (book for curing), composed in 1863. The remaining pages, from p. 54 to the end, are later entriesconcerning births and deaths in the Na family. Manuscript divisions/headings are written in Spanish.References:          Cline, H.F. Guide to Ethnohistorical Sources,; 1150; Weeks, J.M. Mesoamerican Ethnohistory in United States Libraries,; 151Access:              Note:                Image of first pagehttp://libweb5.princeton.edu/visual_materials/gates/images/gates2.jpgNote:                Finding aid or folder listhttp://libweb.princeton.edu/libraries/firestone/rbsc/aids/gates/SUBJECT(S)Descriptor:          Maya calendar.Maya astronomy.Mayas -- Religion.Mayas -- Medicine.Maya language -- Texts.Calendrier maya.Astronomie maya.Mayas -- Religion.Maya (Langue) -- Textes.Maya astronomy.Maya calendar.Maya language.Mayas -- Medicine.Mayas -- Religion.Genre/Form:          Recipes.Manuscripts, Maya -- 19th century.Cookbookrecipes.papers (documents)Texts.Recipes.Recettes.Note(s):             Layout: 1 column, 28 lines./ Decoration: pages decorated with calligraphic birds that embellish initials or stand in the margin; other initials are embellished as a beast with along neck. Decorative elements highlight titles and, in one instance, frame a paragraph./ Gates named this manuscript after the transcribers (Na)./ Published facsimile and translation: The book ofChilam Balam of Na : facsimile, translation, and edited text / Ruth Gubler and David Bolles, editors. Lancaster, Calif. : Labyrinthos, 2000.General Info:        The text indicates that the manuscript was in the hands of the Na family at least until 1896; later acquired by William Gates; sold to Robert Garrett (purchased from WilliamGates in 1930); deposited by Garrett at the Institute of Advanced Studies at Princeton in 1942; removed from the Institute in 1949, at Garrett's request, and donated to the Princeton UniversityLibrary./ Forms part of the Robert Garrett Collection. Preferred citation:  Garrett-Gates Mesoamerican Manuscripts, no. 2, Manuscripts Division, Dept. of Rare Books and Special Collections, PrincetonUniversity Library.; The Ethno-Botany of the Maya / Ralph Loveland Roys. New Orleans, Dept. of Middle American Research : Tulane University of Louisiana, 1931.; Manuscritos de Tekax y Nah /introducción por Héctor M. Calderón. México : Grupo Dzibil, 1981.Other Titles:        Chilam Balam de Nah (Manuscript); Incipit:; Hetu cutal enero: ti Mientotese ...Material Type:       Manuscript (mss)Document Type:       Book; Archival MaterialDate of Entry:       20011113Update:              20220720Accession No:        OCLC:                53848650Provider:        OCLCDatabase:            WorldCat--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Libraries worldwide that own item: 1 Search the HOLLIS CatalogExternal Resources:  Cite This ItemFind Items About:    Chilam Balam de Nah (Manuscript)2Garrett, Robert,max: 37Gates, William,max: 156Title:                Book of the Chilam Balam of Nah :[1857-1896]. manuscript,Author(s):           Garrett, Robert,; 1875-1961, ; donor.Gates, William,; 1863-1940, ; former owner.Place:               Mexico; Yucatán (State); Teabo.Year:                1857-1896Description:         1 volumes (32 leaves) : paper, illustrations ; 23 x 17 cmIn:                  Robert Garrett Collection, ca. 1340 B.C.-1900s.Language:            Mayan languages; Text in Yucatec with some Spanish.Abstract:            Manuscript transcribed by Jose Maria Na and Jose Secundino Na of Teabo, Yucatán. The first p. 30 is signed by Jose Secundino Na and dated December 18, 1857. The final pages aresigned by Jose Maria Nah and dated August 5, 1863. The manuscript is divided into 2 parts: pages 1-30 constitute a liturgical calendar for an unspecified year, includes calendar count, with ancientdaynames, a section on astronomy; p. 30-53 are concerned with diseases and their cures. Page 1 is the seating of January; p. 2 is a correlation of the Gregorian calendar with the Maya months of anunspecified year; p. 3-14 correlates each day of the Gregorian year with the days of the Mayan tzolkin (there are no numbers with the Mayan days); the saint is given for each day, and up to p. 6, itis indicated whether the day has a good omen or bad. Pages 15-30 concern the signs of the zodiac, indicating the significance of the births under particular signs, and the advantages of burning,fields, etc. This portion of the book was composed in 1857. Pages 30-53 are "Libro u tial acob" (book for curing), composed in 1863. The remaining pages, from p. 54 to the end, are later entriesconcerning sporadic births and deaths in the Na family in Teabo in a mixture of Maya and Spanish; the final pages are upside down. Manuscript divisions/headings are written in Spanish. The latestdate is 1896.References:          Cline, H.F. Guide to Ethnohistorical Sources,; 1150; Weeks, J.M. column2: Access:              http://libweb5.princeton.edu/visual_materials/gates/images/gates2.jpgAvailability:        Check the catalogs in your library. Libraries worldwide that own item: 1 Search the HOLLIS CatalogExternal Resources:  Cite This ItemFind Items About:    Chilam Balam de Nah (Manuscript)2Garrett, Robert,max: 37Gates, William,max: 156Title:                [Book of the Chilam Balam of Nah].Author(s):           Garrett, Robert,; 1875-1961, ; donor.Gates, William,; 1863-1940, ; former owner.Place:               Mexico; Yucatán; Teabo.Year:                1857-1863Description:         64 leaves (1 column, 28 lines), bound : paper, illustrations ; 22.5 x 17 cmIn:                  Garrett Collection of Manuscripts in the Indigenous Languages of Middle America. 1500-1968Language:            Mayan languages; Text in Mayan-Yucatec; with some Spanish.Standard No:         Other:               Garrett 3, Yucatec Maya; Gates 2Abstract:            Manuscript transcribed by Jose Maria Na and Jose Secundino Na of Teabo, Yucatan. The first p. 30 is signed by Jose Secundino Na and dated December 18, 1857. The final pages aresigned by Jose Maria Nah and dated August 5, 1863. Manuscript divided into 2 parts: pages 1-30 constitute a liturgical calendar for an unspecified year, includes calendar count, with ancientdaynames, a section on astronomy; p. 30-53 are concerned with diseases and their cures. Page 1 is the seating of January; p. 2 is a correlation of the Gregorian calendar with the Maya months of anunspecified year; p. 3-14 correlates each day of the Gregorian year with the days of the Mayan tzolkin (there are no numbers with the Mayan days); the saint is given for each day, and up to p. 6, itis indicated whether the day has a good omen or bad. Pages 15-30 concern the signs of the zodiac, indicating the significance of the births under particular signs, and the advantages of burning,fields, etc. This portion of the book was composed in 1857. Pages 30-53 are "Libro u tial acob" (book for curing), composed in 1863. The remaining pages, from p. 54 to the end, are later entriesconcerning births and deaths in the Na family. Manuscript divisions/headings are written in Spanish.References:          Cline, H.F. Guide to Ethnohistorical Sources,; 1150; Weeks, J.M. Mesoamerican Ethnohistory in United States Libraries,; 151Access:              Note:                Image of first pagehttp://libweb5.princeton.edu/visual_materials/gates/images/gates2.jpgNote:                Finding aid or folder listhttp://libweb.princeton.edu/libraries/firestone/rbsc/aids/gates/Note:                Search MASC (Manuscripts, Archives, and Special Collections), the database of the Dept. of Rare Books and Special Collections, to find relatedmaterialhttp://libweb5.princeton.edu/masc/MascSearch.aspSUBJECT(S)Descriptor:          Maya calendar.Maya astronomy.Mayas -- Religion.Mayas -- Medicine.Maya language -- Texts.Calendrier maya.Astronomie maya.Mayas -- Religion.Maya (Langue) -- Textes.Maya astronomy.Maya calendar.Maya language.Mayas -- Medicine.Mayas -- Religion.Genre/Form:          Recipes.Manuscripts, Maya -- 19th century.Cookbookrecipes.papers (documents)Texts.Recipes.Recettes.Note(s):             Decoration: pages decorated with calligraphic birds that embellish initials or stand in the margin; other initials are embellished as a beast with a long neck. Decorativeelements highlight titles and, in one instance, frame a paragraph./ Gates named this manuscript after the transcribers (Na)./ Binding: in cloth box./ Published facsimile and translation: The book ofChilam Balam of Na : facsimile, translation, and edited text / Ruth Gubler and David Bolles, editors. Lancaster, Calif. : Labyrinthos, 2000.General Info:        The text indicates that the manuscript was in the hands of the Na family at least until 1896; previously owned by William E. Gates; Garrett obtained the manuscript on Dec. 10,1936./ Forms part of the Garrett Collection of Manuscripts in the Indigenous Languages of Middle America.; The Ethno-Botany of the Maya / Ralph Loveland Roys. New Orleans, Dept. of Middle AmericanResearch : Tulane University of Louisiana, 1931.; Manuscritos de Tekax y Nah / introducción por Héctor M. Calderón. México : Grupo Dzibil, 1981.Other Titles:        Chilam Balam de Nah (Manuscript); Incipit:; Hetu cutal enero: ti Mientotese ...Material Type:       Manuscript (mss)Document Type:       Book; Archival MaterialDate of Entry:       20011113Update:              20220721Accession No:        OCLC:                54746802Provider:        OCLCDatabase:            WorldCat--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Hermannmax: 16Brinton, Daniel Garrison,max: 43Title:                     Coleccion de platicas doctrinales y sermones en lengua mayaAuthor(s):                Berendt, C. Hermann 1817-1878,  (Carl Hermann), compiler.Domínguez y Argáiz, Francisco Eugenio.Carvajal, Francisco Leon,; 1790-1869.Brinton, Daniel Garrison,; 1837-1899, ; former owner.Publication:              Yucatan de Merida,Year:                     1868-1870Description:              144 leaves : paper ; 191 x 121 mm. bound to 198 x 135 mm. + 2 leaves.In:                       Berendt-Brinton Linguistic Collection. Item 46 and Item 47Language:                 Spanish; Spanish and Maya.Abstract:                 19th-century copies of various talks and sermons in the Maya language from the 18th and 19th centuries.References:               Described in Brinton, Daniel Garrison. Catalogue of the Berendt Linguistic Collection (Department of Archaeology and Paleontology, University of Pennsylvania, 1900),; pp.12-13 (nos. 46-47).; Described in Weeks, John M. "Karl Hermann Berendt: Colección de manuscritos lingüistícos de Centroamérica y Mesoamérica," Mesoamérica 36 (Dec. 1998),; pp. 652-653,645, 677 (nos. 76, 52, 159).; Described in Weeks, John M. The Library of Daniel Garrison Brinton (University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, 2002),; pp. 143, 109, 337 (nos.1315, 903, 3830).SUBJECT(S)Descriptor:               Sermons, Maya.Sacraments -- Catholic Church -- Handbooks, manuals, etc.Maya language -- Texts.Mayan languages -- Texts -- Early works to 1800.Indians of Mexico -- Languages -- Early works to 1800.Sacrements -- Église catholique -- Guides, manuels, etc.Maya (Langue) -- Textes.Langues maya-quiché -- Textes -- Ouvrages avant 1800.Indians of Mexico -- Languages.Language and languages.Maya language.Mayan languages.Sacraments -- Catholic Church.Named Corp:               Catholic Church -- Sermons.Église catholique -- Sermons.Catholic Church.Genre/Form:               Manuscripts, Mexican -- 19th century.Manuscripts, Spanish -- 19th century.Manuscripts, Latin American.Codices.sermons.Translations.Early works.Handbooks and manuals.Sermons.Texts.Sermons.Sermons.Geographic:               Mexico -- Languages -- Early works to 1800.Mexique -- Langues -- Ouvrages avant 1800.Mexico.Note(s):                  Ms. codex./ Collective title from general title page for the volume (p. [i])./ 1. p. 1-37: Platicas de los principales mysterios de nuestra Santa Fee / Francisco EugenioDominguez y Argaiz./ 2. p. 77-116: Discurso para el Descendimiento del Señor / Francisco Carvajal./ 3. p. 118-229: Sermones en lengua maya./ 4. p. 231-257: Modo de confesar en lengua maya./ DanielGarrison Brinton assigned individual item numbers to the second (Item 46) and third (Item 47) works in this manuscript in his 1900 Catalogue; they have individual records that may be searched bytitle containing more detailed information. The first item is a manuscript copy of the preliminary material in Spanish and the first two sermons in Maya (on Catholic principles and the Trinity) fromDomínguez y Argáiz's book of the same title printed in 1758. The fourth item is a copy of the beginning of a handbook on confession with the text in Spanish on the left page and Maya on the rightpage of each opening. The original manuscript of the handbook, dated 1803, is also in this collection (Ms. Coll. 700, Item 26); the copy corresponds to approximately the first seven pages of theoriginal./ A map or schematic drawing that was pasted inside the lower cover and a loose page of notes about the third work have been removed and are shelved with the manuscript./ Pagination: Paper,144; [ii], 285, [i] (pp. 38-76 and 258-285 blank); page numbers stamped in blue ink, upper outer corners./ Script: Written in the hand of C. Hermann Berendt./ Binding: Late 19th-century leather,rebacked with cloth; marbled edges./ Origin: Copied in Mérida, Mexico, 1868-1870./ Also available on microfilm (Museum Library Microfilm Reels no. 5, 22), Museum Library, University ofPennsylvania. A photocopy of this manuscript is shelved with the manuscript.General Info:             From the collection of C. Hermann Berendt, later acquired by Daniel Garrison Brinton (ex libris stamp on title page). Preferred citation:       UPenn Ms. Coll. 700, Item 46and Item 47.Other Titles:             Platicas de los principales mysterios de nuestra Santa Fee.; Discurso para el Descendimiento del Señor.; Sermones en lengua maya.; Modo de confesar en lengua maya.Responsibility:           por diferentes autores.Material Type:            Manuscript (mss)Document Type:            Book; Archival MaterialDate of Entry:            20070315Update:                   20220407Accession No:             OCLC:                     124560095Provider:        OCLCDatabase:                 WorldCat--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
